quoteFirst: While in rest billets Tommy gets up
quoteLast: , washes up, answers roll call, is inspected by his platoon officer, and has breakfast. At 8.45 he parades (drills) with his company or goes on fatigue according to the orders which have been read out by the Orderly Sergeant the night previous.
title:
"Over the Top," by an American Soldier Who Went
Together with Tommy's Dictionary of the Trenches
author: Empey, Arthur Guy, 1883-1963

quoteFirst: This officer set out
quoteTime: about six o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: for the heights over Balaklava. On passing through the French camp he called upon General Vinoy to inform him of the change which the weather had effected in the plans agreed upon, but the General said he thought it would be better to move down his men to support Sir Colin in case the latter should have advanced before the counter-orders reached him.
title: The British Expedition to the Crimea
author: Russell, William Howard, Sir, 1820-1907

quoteFirst: But the waiters vowed they knew nothing of the gentleman; the whole party had been perfect strangers, and they had no idea as to where they had gone on. So this enraged young Englishman spent the third night of his honeymoon in a hunt round the haunts of Paris, but with no success; and at
quoteTime: about six o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: came back baffled but still raging, and thoroughly wearied out.
title: The Reason Why
author: Glyn, Elinor, 1864-1943

quoteFirst: _January 21st._--A black-letter day for Kut in general and myself in particular.
quoteLast: in the pitch-dark, the water burst into our front line by Redoubt D and flooded the trenches up to one's neck. All the careful and dogged efforts of our sappers could not stop it.
title:
The Secrets of a Kuttite
An Authentic Story of Kut, Adventures in Captivity and Stamboul Intrigue
author: Mousley, Edward O. (Edward Opotiki), 1886-

quoteFirst: The weather cleared up at
quoteLast: : and we travelled across a good soil, throughout the whole of this day's journey. The country appeared but thinly wooded, and without any hill or watercourse.

quoteFirst: It was
quoteTime: about six o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: when Mr. Walter went into the press-room, and astonished its occupants by telling them that 'The _Times_ was already printed by steam! That if they attempted violence, there was a force ready to suppress it; but that if they were peaceable, their wages should be continued to every one of them till similar employment could be procured,'--a promise which was, no doubt, faithfully performed; and having so said, he distributed several copies among them.
title: Triumphs of Invention and Discovery in Art and Science
author: Fyfe, J. Hamilton (James Hamilton), 1837-1880

quoteFirst: A flat, smooth, oval slab, weighing about fifteen pounds, and a stone roller six inches in diameter, worked with both hands, and the weight of the body kneeling ungracefully upon it on "all fours," are used to triturate the holcus grain. At times water must be sprinkled over the meal, until a finely powdered paste is ready for the oven: thus several hours' labour is required to prepare a few pounds of bread.
title: First Footsteps in East Africa
author: Burton, Richard Francis, Sir, 1821-1890

quoteFirst: Miss Moore lay awake nearly the whole night. She heard, though in less degree, the old noises; and in the early morning (compare our first night) heard the sound of women's voices talking. When I awoke,

quoteFirst: For the bull train there were two halts each day: at noon and at evening, when the wagons were corralled, usually by the right and left wing, the oxen unyoked, and camp made for rest and meals. Then, about one o’clock and
quoteLast: , the march was resumed. The men walked beside their wheel cattle and by stepping out a little and “throwing” the whip to the full extent of lash, stock and arm, they could flick the backs of their lead cattle.
title:
Buffalo Bill and the Overland Trail
Being the story of how boy and man worked hard and played hard to blaze the white trail, by wagon train, stage coach and pony express, across the great plains and the mountains beyond, that the American republic might expand and flourish
author: Sabin, Edwin L. (Edwin Legrand), 1870-1952; Stephens, Charles H., 1851-1931 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Brown of the same Town came along with him, and they afforded me much Comfort; they told me they never saw the like, and it was God’s handy Work, and not Man’s, so taking leave of me, they wished that the God of Heaven might be my Physician, and it gave me a merry Heart and cheerful Countenance, and gave them Thanks for what Favours I had received from them, and my Pains still ceased. Abundance came both far and near all the Week to see me, and amongst the rest a Surgeon, who persuaded me to have the Bone of my right Leg taken off, to which I gave Consent. On the 25th
quoteLast: , when I arose and opened the Cloaths, I found my Legs were fallen from me, and the Pains I then suffered were not worthy to be called Pains; so I dressed it with the same Medicine I made use of before; within two Hours after came several People to visit me.
title: Devonshire Characters and Strange Events
author: Baring-Gould, S. (Sabine), 1834-1924

quoteFirst: The Prince returned and call'd out, 'There is no help for it, my lads; march back to Culloden House.' Back they marched to Culloden House (the Prince bringing up the rear) where the bulk of them arrived
quoteLast: . The Prince after ordering and earnestly recommending to everybody to do their utmost to get provisions to his men went into the house, threw himself upon the top of a bed, boots, etc., upon him; but in a few hours, being alarmed with the approach of the enemy he hurried to the field, and endeavoured to put his men in order by drawing them up in two lines.
title:
The Lyon in Mourning, Vol. 1
or a collection of speeches, letters, journals, etc. relative to the affairs of Prince Charles Edward Stuart
author: Forbes, Robert, 1708-1775; Paton, Henry [Editor]
